text:
Hello - I am trying to create an association of a contact to a company using this JS code  : <https://gist.github.com/sas70/9ef4c6c74b6d6c9c48f1bf1c83a3b036>
While the create new contact & new companies steps are successful, I get this 404 error code : “Error: Hey, Your Request failed: 404 Not Found” at line 64 when I fetch the url. Appreciate any feedback :slightly_smiling_face:

Saw this article today <https://developers.HubSpot.com/blog/how-to-use-npm-packages-in-custom-code-workflow-actions> . Cool way to handle it, but I can't imagine HubSpot would want this to happen? Wouldn't this open the door to backdoors from insecure packages that HubSpot wouldn't be able to track since its compiled down? Wondering the thoughts before we actually implement it at all <@UQNEXHW14> <@U03MLCLS5BN> <@U01NMMDTERZ>

Well you could already do whatever you want pretty much using CCAs, with Josh's approach you can now bundle in packages a little easier. If you're doing this type of thing you are probably smart enough to know how to keep your data safe... That's just my opinion though
The real problem is the load times on the lambdas, lol
Yeah I agree _but_ we typically hand stuff off and don't maintain it so thats my concern
also it probably makes debugging a nightmare lol
debugging would be a nightmare for sure
CC <@U02BW35KW7J>
ty Carter
Hey <@U04N6N424MB>

I guess my concern is also if a outside package that is now compiled into the cca did something like logging all the process.env on the workflow and then sending it back to mothership lol , granted it could do that anyways outside of CCA but figure itd be harder to track in a CCA

Long-time lurker, first-time speaker :slightly_smiling_face: One option, when you spot this sort of stuff, is to work with the advocates to create content (video or blog) yourself. As you know, in the tech world, anyone can poke holes in anything. We love being able to share that voice. For example, why not do a post on security?
not poking holes, just want to make sure whatever we do is future proof and sanctioned without having to go back to the well if its decided its not kosher
Would love to get a security post!
i'll be honest: this seems to take away _some_ of the reason for serverless functions....I can't see HubSpot cutting off its own tail in that manner

yeah it's really not the most future proof (HubSpot could change the time limits and that would throw everything off if that was the first time the workflow was compiling), definitely still think the best thing is to setup your own apis or lambdas for some of the more advanced things
I personally feels like it helps shows the possibilities of serverless functions (same things as CCAs) and in that way sells more people on enterprise

yeah...I mean I would love to utilize this to load in simple packages that should already be there like lodash without having to convince people to buy a serverless function but just think a official "go ahead and do it" would be nice
Yes that's true, don't think HubSpot would ever tell you not to do it though, serverless functions, CCAs, custom actions, are all user driven things
fair enough....im just still butthurt over losing our developer accounts lol
they were built so that HubSpot wouldn't have to build out some of these things, and instead pass the responsibility on to the user
<@U01QVR44MEY> If you check out the repo, I don’t talk about it in the blog post, but I include some stuff for local debugging which can actually make it easier in some ways
yep ran a couple of tests and built out a couple on my end

And fully agree with you Thomas, I wish we had a way to just do it, but until then I am happy with this approach. And one of my preferred things to do with this is load in some bigger packages like the Stripe client, which if that had security issues I think their would be more important people with bigger things to worry about.
But as always blah blah blah check the packages you’re using yourself
fair, but you always do have situations like this <https://www.techtarget.com/searchsecurity/news/252525968/NPM-malware-attack-goes-unnoticed-for-a-year>
lol yeah I remember
Absolutely fair, but when you do this your code is hard pinned to a specific version, so if you are checking the code, and at a minimum making sure it’s not making a web request you should be fine.
no worries - its a neat trick. just would like more assurance from HubSpot that its ok to use outside of a blog (this isn't on you at all, its on them)
Well, I guess here it was fake API discord clients, so you’ll have to do a bit more work then checking that there’s no web requests.
Yeah that’s totally fair, potentially some disclaimer about NPM and security could be helpful
Found the issue by looking at another piece of the docs: <https://developers.HubSpot.com/docs/api/crm/associations/v3>.  I basically fixed the url structure & the request body. Thanks
